messageBody:
I have recently taken on a project to setup a unit testing framework
for my development team, but I have run into several technical
issues.

Our application is a multi-tier application that uses EJBs
extensively. Because of its distributed nature, objects are
constantly passed around between tiers. Since these object are
distributed, we use a unique identifier (a primary key in a database)
to distinguish between objects.

The business objects used in our applications all derive from one
high-level business object, called BaseBusinessObject. In order to
allow for the correct comparison of objects in the distributed
environment, the decision was made to override the .equals() method
in BaseBusinessObject to compare the primary keys of two objects.
This allows us, for example, to remove a business object from a
Vector because the Vector's remove() method internally calls
the .equals() method. We obviously can't compare the objects in the
Vector by reference, the default .equals() behavior, because they may
be distributed objects and thus wouldn't have the same reference.

The problem lies in the fact that we want to be able to
override .equals() in derived business objects to compare their
attributes by value. This is of course the way that assertEquals()
works in the junit framework. If we override the .equals() method,
then there are implications for methods on collections, such as remove
() on a Vector.

There are many articles that explain how to write unit tests with the
assumption that the .equals() method can be overridden, but there
doesn't seem to be any documentation on how to test an application
that uses distributed objects in which you can't override .equals().
It seems that this would be a very common problem, but I can't seem
to find anything on it.

We have a few ideas on how to get around this problem, but I was
hoping that someone may be able to shine some light on the issue
before we implement an unnecessarily crude solution.
